Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Impacts of Unprecedented Shift to Online Learning on Students' Cognitive Load and Readiness for Self-Directed Learning
Award.AbstractNarration: Engineering students learn to become engineers through a curriculum of challenging, carefully sequenced courses. Disruption of this sequence may lead to poor performance, exit from the major or college, and extended time to graduation. These negative student outcomes could in turn damage national economic competitiveness by limiting the number of engineers available to enter the workforce. This project will gather time-sensitive data to investigate the impact of the rapid shift to online instruction due to COVID-19. In contrast to their highly structured in-person classes. virtual environments place much greater responsibility on students to manage their own learning, As a result, undergraduate students, including those at military academic institutions such as the Citadel, are experiencing increased mental demands (i.e. cognitive load) as they tackle the rigors of engineering coursework, while simultaneously exercising self-directed learning skills. This project will gather and analyse data about the impact of online courses on the cognitive load and self-directed learning readiness of Citadel engineering students. This information has the potential to be broadly applicable to undergraduate engineering education, as well as to other STEM disciplines and to education levels before and beyond college.<br/><br/>The project focuses on a unique and under-represented population of engineering students who, under normal circumstances, must complete military training in addition to satisfying academic requirements. Students’ cognitive load and self-directed learning readiness will be measured using established survey instruments and student focus groups before and after the shift to online learning, as well as after the return to on-campus operations. Three research questions, undergirded by cognitive load theory, will guide the investigations: (1) How do students’ cognitive loads and/or self-directed learning readiness differ between in-person and online course? (2) To what extent are changes in self-directed learning readiness associated with changes in cognitive load? (3) Which demographic factors (if any) impact changes in cognitive load and self-directed learning readiness? The project team will use a mixed methods approach to analyze the qualitative and quantitative data collected from surveys and focus groups to determine the magnitude and duration of changes in students’ cognitive load and self-directed learning readiness. Findings from the proposed work have the potential to advance knowledge related to students’ online learning experiences that can aid in improving course offerings as part of regular instruction, as well as situations in which continuity of instruction is threatened. The intellectual merit of the project lies in its potential to contribute to foundational knowledge relating to issues of sudden and drastic shifts in educational environments as experienced by diverse students at a military institution. The broader impacts of the project lie in its potential to gather time-sensitive data that will permit significant contributions to our understanding of how undergraduate military student learners adapt to disruptive change in their learning environments. This RAPID award is made by the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education program in the Division of Undergraduate Education (Education and Human Resources Directorate), using funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The COVID-19 pandemic led to unprecedented changes to how and when engineering students learn.  At The Citadel, a public undergraduate military institution in the Southeastern United States, face-to-face classes were quickly transitioned to emergency online course delivery at the Spring 2020 semester midterm.  Subsequently, in the 2021/2022 academic year, classes were administered in a HyFlex modality where students alternated in-person and virtual attendance.  We expected that shifting course delivery modalities could impact student workload and development.  In engineering, high workload can be a normal part of learning; however, excessively high workload is known to disrupt learning.  Thus, we thought perhaps manageable increases in workload might lead to positive outcomes, such as development of self-directed learning skills as students adapt to their new online learning environment.  Self-directed learning is very important for engineers, as they must continue to learn throughout their professional careers to stay up-to-date on new technologies and design practices. 

We found student workload to be particularly high during emergency online, using data generated from the NASA Task Load Index (TLX). The NASA TLX is a short survey that allowed students to rate their workload based on several workload sources (mental demand, temporal demand, effort, performance, and frustration) during different course delivery modalities.  Statistically, we found total workload (and nearly all workload sources) to be considerably higher in engineering courses during emergency online, as compared to face-to-face, learning.  Student demographics may have impacted their workload experiences during emergency online learning, with middle-years students (sophomores and juniors), women, and active duty/veteran students reporting especially high increases in some workload sources. 

While students were experiencing higher workload, they also reported statistically significant increases in self-directed learning readiness.  At several times during the pandemic, our students completed the self-directed learning readiness scale (SDLRS), a survey with 58 questions related to attitudes towards and preferences for learning.  Nearly 60% of students reported an increase in self-directed learning readiness during the six weeks of emergency online learning, which is notable because few other studies have documented meaningful changes in self-directed learning readiness among engineering students.  Generally, improvement in self-directed learning readiness was observed only for students who experienced an increase in 2 or 3 workload sources, which supports that increased workload encourages learning and development.  Students who were not challenged (i.e., those that reported increase in less than 2 workload sources) or those that felt overloaded (i.e., those experiencing increases in more than 3 workload sources) may not have fully benefited from emergency online learning. 

Synthesizing the results from our study, we believe that planned online learning experiences could be strategically designed to support development of self-directed learning skills, as long as student workload remains manageable.  In particular, faculty should consider that workload may vary between individual students, even for the same learning environment.  Workload monitoring during online learning using the NASA TLX could provide faculty with needed information to provide learning experiences that foster self-directed learning through appropriate workload.
